ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks decline on pessimism whether a phase 1 deal can be completed this year and after US President Trump suggested China is not stepping up, although cautious optimism by China Vice Premier Liu He provides mild relief
content:
Asia markets are lower across the board with risk sentiment rattled by increased trade pessimism after source reports noted the US-China phase one deal may not be completed this year and US President Trump suggested China is not stepping up to the level he wants. In addition, the House passage of the Hong Kong rights bill which President Trump is expected to sign, adds another front to the trade uncertainty. ASX 200 (-0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) are lower with the declines in Australia led by underperformance in trade sensitive sectors such as tech, materials, miners and industrials, while Tokyo exporters suffer the ill effects from safe haven flows into the domestic currency. Hang Seng (-1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) are also downbeat on the trade-related doubts and with China media outlets continuing to voice their backlash to the US ‘interference’, while the PBoC also refrained from liquidity operations and with the losses in Hong Kong snowballing as all components in its benchmark index initially resided in the red, although their was mild relief following comments from Chinese Vice Premier Liu He who was cautiously optimistic about reaching an agreement and remains confident despite being confused regarding US demands.

In FX markets, the DXY is slightly softer amid the US-China trade uncertainty and following a pullback from resistance around the 98.00 level, while the prior session’s FOMC Minutes provided little to sway the currency as most Fed policymakers judged that after the October 30th rate cut, the policy level would be appropriate barring a material reassessment of the outlook. The greenback’s major counterpart’s are relatively stable and hold on to the prior day’s gains with EUR/USD steadily edging closer towards a large option expiry for today’s New Yok cut at 1.1090, while GBP/USD prods yesterday’s highs as the latest Savanta/ComRes poll shows the Conservatives lead widening with support at 42% (+1) vs. Labour at 31% (-2) and Europe Elects seat projection also suggests the Conservatives are likely to get a majority in Parliament with a projected 354 seats. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was subdued by the risk appetite but found mild relief after the comments from China’s Vice Premier and top trade negotiator, while antipodeans are lacklustre due to their high-beta statuses, China trade exposure and following a weaker CNY reference rate setting.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher with prices underpinned by safe-haven demand although gains are capped as advances in T-notes stalled around the 130.00 level and with the BoJ only in the market today for Treasury Discount bills.

Other News - China State Council says the nation will continue to reduce the tax burden on individuals by improving and better implementing the special individual income tax deduction mechanism, while it added current tax breaks for first 9-months total CNY 440bln for 250mln individuals. (Newswires)

 

Hong Kong

US House has voted to pass the Hong Kong bill as expected and sends it to US President Trump for signature or veto, while source reports later noted President Trump is expected to sign the Hong Kong bill. (Newswires)

People's Daily commentary stated the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act is a piece of wastepaper that interferes in China's internal affairs, while CNBC's Yoon tweeted that China will double down on attacks of US Congress after the House passed legislation supporting Hong Kong Protesters. (Twitter)

 

Trade

US President Trump says he doesn't think China is stepping up to the level he wants in trade talks and that China wants a trade deal more than he does. US President Trump had earlier stated that we continue to talk with China which wants a deal and suggested that the question is if he wants to make a deal because he likes what's happening right now with the US taking in billions and billions of dollars. (Newswires/Twitter)

Phase One US-China trade deal may not be completed this year, according to reports citing trade experts and people close to the White House.  The reports added that US President Trump and US Trade Representative Lighthizer recognize that rolling back tariffs for a deal that fails to address core intellectual property and technology transfer issues will not be seen as a good deal for the US. In addition, there were reports in People's Daily that cited Chinese President Xi's trip to Brazil as the last international trip for him this year which suggests no international trade deal signing is scheduled. (Newswires)

White House Deputy Press Secretary said negotiations are continuing and progress is being made on the text of the US-China phase one agreement. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department confirmed that it has begun issuing some licenses to some US companies to supply non-sensitive goods to Huawei, while companies are receiving a mix of approvals and denials of requests to sell to Huawei from the US Commerce department. There were also comments from US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said 290 applications have been accepted for the Huawei special license, according to FBN's Edward Lawrence. (Newswires/Twitter/Fox)

Chinese Global Times Editor tweeted that few Chinese believe that China and the US can achieve a trade deal soon, while he added that belief is that the significance of a potential deal will be limited and are prepared for prolonged trade war. (Twitter)

Both China and the US will not want to link the US Senate's recently passed Hong Kong Human Rights bill to current trade talks, according to CNBC's Yoon who spoke to Chinese academics in Hong Kong. CNBC's Yoon also tweeted in response to US President Trump's comments of China not stepping up, in which she stated the Chinese feel US is the one that needs to make the next move with tariff rollbacks to show sincerity, make deal “balanced” and give Beijing face. (Twitter)
